16.summary: Classical Shia exegetes emphasize that the phrase "whatever they wish" (mā yashā'ūn) transcends mere material gratification. In Surah Al-Furqan, verse 16, Allah (swt) describes the eternal rewards awaiting the righteous in Paradise: *"For them therein is whatever they wish, [while] abiding eternally. It is ever upon your Lord a promise [worthy to be] requested. "* This verse, revealed during the Meccan period when early Muslims faced severe persecution, served as a reminder of divine justice and the impermanence of worldly struggles. Imam Ali (as) states, *"Paradise is the abode of those who recognise the Truth in its essence"* (Bihar al-Anwar), emphasizing that true "desires" in Paradise transcend material wants, reflecting instead the soul’s yearning for nearness to Allah through love for His chosen ones. For Shia Muslims, this verse resonates with the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who exemplified unwavering trust in Allah’s justice amid trials, inspiring followers to view life’s challenges as pathways to eternal closeness to the Divine.

17.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqaan verse 17, Allah paints a vivid scene of the Day of Judgment, where He gathers humanity alongside the false deities they worshipped — idols, worldly obsessions, or misguided ideologies. The verse’s rhetorical question, **"Did you mislead these servants of Mine, or did they themselves stray from the way?"** underscores a profound theological truth: both the worshipped falsehoods and those who chose to worship them will be held accountable. The Arabic term **"aḍlaltum"** (you misled) shifts blame onto the powerless idols, exposing their inability to guide or harm, while **"ḍallū al-sabīl"** (they strayed from the way) highlights human responsibility for abandoning divine guidance.

Historically, this verse challenged Mecca’s polytheists who attributed power to hand-carved idols, exposing the absurdity of worshipping created objects over the Creator. Shia tafsir, like Tafsir al-Mizan by Allamah Tabatabai, emphasizes that "what they worship besides Allah" extends beyond physical idols to include any force or ideology that replaces divine authority — a timeless warning against elevating worldly leaders, desires, or systems above God’s commandments.

In contemporary life, this verse urges self-reflection: What "idols" do we prioritise over Allah? Wealth, social status, or blind allegiance to flawed ideologies can all become modern **taghut** (false deities). Practically, it calls Muslims to align their lives with the Qur’an and the purified guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, who serve as beacons against misguidance. Imam Ali’s teachings remind us that true freedom lies in rejecting all forms of spiritual slavery, choosing conscious submission to Allah over passive following of trends. By regularly auditing our loyalties and seeking knowledge, we fortify ourselves against straying — fulfilling our role as accountable, thinking servants of the One who defines the Straight Path.
17.layer2:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:17), classical Shia exegetes emphasize Allah’s profound interrogation of both misguided worshippers and the false objects of their devotion, framing this as a definitive demonstration of divine justice (*‘adl*) and human accountability. Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, interprets the verse as a theatrical unveiling of truth on the Day of Judgment, where Allah compels idols, false deities, or worldly powers worshipped besides Him — whether physical idols, human tyrants, or abstract ideologies — to confront their incapacity to guide or misguide. Their silence, as Tabatabai notes, exposes the inherent fallacy of polytheism (*shirk*) and underscores humanity’s moral responsibility (*taklif*) to discern truth through divine guidance.

Shaykh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* elaborates that the rhetorical question posed by Allah — “Did you mislead them, or did they stray?” — serves not to seek information but to establish a cosmic “court” where both oppressors and oppressed bear witness against themselves. This aligns with the Shia theological tenet that misguidance originates in human choice (*ikhtiyar*), while true guidance flows solely through Allah’s mercy and the Ahl al-Bayt’s intercession. The verse thus implicitly critiques those who blindly follow corrupt authorities or ideologies, neglecting the divinely appointed Imams as the “straight path” (*sirat al-mustaqim*). 

The discourse also ties to Shia eschatology, where false claimants to authority — including tyrannical rulers who usurped the Imams’ rights — will be exposed as powerless intercessors. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq elucidated, such verses reaffirm the necessity of *walaya* (allegiance to divine guides) to avoid spiritual deviation. This interplay between human agency, divine justice, and the ontological void of false deities remains central to Shia theological and jurisprudential frameworks, reinforcing the linkage between creed (*aqida*) and ethical practice (*‘amal*)
17.layer3:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:17), the Quran paints a vivid scene of divine accountability, questioning both those who misguide and those who choose misguidance. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, emphasize that the verse speaks to modern forms of idolatry—not merely stone idols, but ideologies like hyper-materialism, unchecked capitalism, or digital addiction that dominate human priorities. These “false deities” distract from Allah-consciousness, a theme echoed by thinkers like Sayyed Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, who linked societal corruption to the abandonment of ethical monotheism.  

Philosophically, the verse raises questions about agency and influence. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali integrate psychological insights, noting how social conformity and cognitive biases (e.g., groupthink) can lead communities astray, blurring the line between active deception and passive straying. This duality mirrors modern debates on accountability in systems of oppression: Are individuals responsible for their choices within exploitative structures, or are they victims of systemic indoctrination?  

The verse’s call to “straying from the way” resonates in global crises like climate denialism, where vested interests mislead the public, and individuals rationalize inaction. Interfaith parallels emerge here: Buddhist teachings on attachment, Christian critiques of Mammon worship, and secular humanist warnings about consumerism all align with the Quranic critique of misdirected worship.  

In multicultural societies, this verse invites reflection on how to uphold divine ethics amid relativism. Contemporary Shia scholarship, as articulated by figures like Dr. Liyakat Takim, stresses that the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings offer a compass against such existential drift, urging communities to prioritize justice, humility, and ecological stewardship—timeless antidotes to modern spiritual disorientation.
17.layer4:
On the Day when Allah gathers humanity alongside their false objects of worship, the verse unveils a profound spiritual reality: every soul will stand accountable not merely for outward idolatry, but for the inward choice between divine guidance and self-devised misdirection. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that "what they worship besides Allah" extends beyond stone idols to include blind obedience to tyrannical rulers, worldly desires, and egotistical whims that eclipse recognition of Truth. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "The utmost worship is recognizing Allah through His signs and adhering to His Guardians (Awliya)." This verse thus becomes a mirror for self-reflection: do we follow the *Taghut* (false powers) or anchor ourselves to the golden chain of *Wilayah*?

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) elucidates this verse's hidden dimension: "Those who claim to love us but oppose our teachings are like one who sculpts an idol then denies worshipping it." Here, the Imam reveals that straying from the *Sirat al-Mustaqim* (Straight Path) occurs when one rejects the Imams' spiritual authority while professing faith superficially. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) warned in her Fadak sermon: "Beware lest the reins of guidance slip from your hands by clinging to the rope of wayward leaders."

Practical wisdom emerges: true servants safeguard their souls by anchoring every thought and action to the teachings of the Fourteen Infallibles. Each day becomes a microcosm of that Final Gathering—will we let temporal distractions mislead us, or walk the illuminated path of the Ahlul Bayt? Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) guides us in Sahifa Sajjadiya: "O Allah! Make me among those who, when trial darkens, hold fast to the rope of Your love and the Household of Your Prophet." Thus, this verse is a call to purify intentions, constantly realign with divine guardianship, and embody the Imams' luminous example in daily life.

فلسفیانہ طور پر ، آیت ایجنسی اور اثر و رسوخ کے بارے میں سوالات اٹھاتی ہے۔ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے اسکالرز نفسیاتی بصیرت کو مربوط کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ کس طرح معاشرتی موافقت اور علمی تعصب (جیسے ، گروپ ٹینک) کمیونٹیز کو گمراہ کرسکتے ہیں ، جو فعال دھوکہ دہی اور غیر فعال بھٹکے کے مابین لائن کو دھندلا دیتے ہیں۔ یہ دوہری ظلم و ستم کے نظاموں میں احتساب کے بارے میں جدید مباحثوں کی آئینہ دار ہے: کیا استحصال کے ڈھانچے میں ان کے انتخاب کے ذمہ دار افراد ہیں ، یا وہ نظامی تعزیر کا شکار ہیں؟  

آیت کی "راہ سے بھٹکنے" کی کال آب و ہوا سے انکار جیسے عالمی بحرانوں میں گونجتی ہے ، جہاں مفادات عوام کو گمراہ کرتے ہیں ، اور افراد غیر عملی کو عقلی حیثیت دیتے ہیں۔ انٹرفیتھ کے متوازی یہاں سامنے آتے ہیں: بدھ مت کی تعلیمات سے متعلق بدھ مت کی تعلیمات ، میمون کی عبادت کے مسیحی تنقید ، اور صارفیت کے بارے میں سیکولر ہیومنسٹ انتباہات سب غلط ہدایت کے قرآنی نقاد کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہیں۔  

کثیر الثقافتی معاشروں میں ، یہ آیت اس بات کی عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے کہ نسبت پسندی کے درمیان الہی اخلاقیات کو کس طرح برقرار رکھا جائے۔ عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ ، جیسا کہ ڈاکٹر لییاکات تکیم جیسے اعداد و شمار کے ذریعہ بیان کیا گیا ہے ، اس بات پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ اہل بیت کی تعلیمات اس طرح کے وجودی بڑھنے کے خلاف ایک کمپاس پیش کرتی ہیں ، جس سے معاشروں کو انصاف ، عاجزی اور ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری کو ترجیح دینے پر زور دیا جاتا ہے۔

اس دن جب اللہ انسانیت کو ان کی عبادت کے جھوٹے چیزوں کے ساتھ جمع کرتا ہے ، آیت ایک گہری روحانی حقیقت کی نقاب کشائی کرتی ہے: ہر روح محض ظاہری بت پرستی کے لئے نہیں بلکہ الہی رہنمائی اور خود سے وابستہ غلط سمت کے مابین اندرونی انتخاب کے لئے جوابدہ کھڑی ہوگی۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن ہے) یہ سکھاتا ہے کہ "وہ اللہ کے علاوہ کیا عبادت کرتے ہیں" پتھر کے بتوں سے آگے بڑھتا ہے تاکہ وہ ظالم حکمرانوں ، دنیاوی خواہشات اور مغربی خواہشات کی اندھی اطاعت کو بھی شامل کریں جو حقیقت کو تسلیم کرتے ہیں۔ امام علی (ان پر امن ہے) ناہج البالاگھا میں کہا گیا ہے: "انتہائی پوجا اپنی علامتوں کے ذریعہ اللہ کو پہچان رہی ہے اور اپنے سرپرستوں (اولیہ) کے ساتھ عمل پیرا ہے۔" اس طرح یہ آیت خود عکاسی کا آئینہ بن جاتی ہے: کیا ہم *ٹیگوت *(جھوٹی طاقتوں) کی پیروی کرتے ہیں یا خود کو *ولیہ *کی سنہری زنجیر پر لنگر انداز کرتے ہیں؟

امام جعفر السادق (اس پر امن ہے) اس آیت کی پوشیدہ جہت کو واضح کرتا ہے: "جو لوگ ہم سے پیار کرنے کا دعوی کرتے ہیں لیکن ہماری تعلیمات کی مخالفت کرتے ہیں وہ ایسے ہی ہیں جو ایک بت کو مجسمہ دیتے ہیں اور پھر اس کی عبادت سے انکار کرتے ہیں۔" یہاں ، امام سے پتہ چلتا ہے کہ * سیرت المطتقیم * (سیدھا راستہ) سے بھٹکنے سے اس وقت ہوتا ہے جب کوئی شخص کو سطحی طور پر ایمان کا دعوی کرتے ہوئے اماموں کے روحانی اتھارٹی کو مسترد کرتا ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن) نے اپنے فڈک خطبے میں متنبہ کیا: "ہوشیار رہو کہ آپ کے ہاتھوں سے رہنمائی کی لگام راہداری کے رہنماؤں کی رسی سے لپٹ کر پھسلیں۔"

عملی حکمت ابھرتی ہے: سچے خادم چودہ انفلیبلز کی تعلیمات کے مطابق ہر سوچ اور عمل کو لنگر انداز کرکے اپنی جانوں کی حفاظت کرتے ہیں۔ ہر دن اس آخری اجتماع کا ایک مائکروکومسم بن جاتا ہے - کیا ہم دنیاوی خلفشار ہمیں گمراہ کرنے دیں گے ، یا اہل بائٹ کے روشن راستے پر چلیں گے؟ امام زین العبدین (اس پر امن ہے) ساہفا سججدیہ میں ہماری رہنمائی کرتا ہے: "اے اللہ! مجھے ان لوگوں میں شامل کریں جو ، جب آزمائش تاریک ہوجاتے ہیں تو ، اپنی محبت کی رسی اور اپنے نبی کے گھریلو کو تیزی سے روکیں۔" اس طرح ، یہ آیت ارادوں کو پاک کرنے ، الہی سرپرستی کے ساتھ مستقل طور پر دوبارہ ترتیب دینے ، اور روز مرہ کی زندگی میں اماموں کی برائٹ مثال کو مجسم بنانے کی کال ہے۔
17.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 25:17, both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge on core theological principles while diverging in nuanced emphases. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia), agree the verse establishes divine accountability for polytheism, with rhetorical questioning underscoring the futility of worshipping powerless entities. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) both emphasize that the addressed "objects of worship" – whether idols, human leaders, or abstract concepts – cannot respond, exposing the absurdity of shirk (idolatry). This shared understanding reinforces the Quranic theme of human responsibility for spiritual deviation.

Key interpretive differences emerge regarding the nature of misguidance. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi and Razi focus on individual moral agency, interpreting the verse as affirming human free will (ikhtiyar) in choosing disbelief despite prophetic warnings. In contrast, Shia commentators such as Tusi and Qummi contextualize the "straying from the way" within their theological framework of necessary divine guidance (huda), implicitly linking proper "way" adherence to allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt. While Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) avoids explicit sectarian references, his emphasis on the verse demonstrating humanity's need for "true guides" resonates with Shia imamate doctrines.

These differences reflect distinct historical developments in Islamic thought. The Sunni focus on individual accountability aligns with early theological debates on qadar (divine decree), while Shia interpretations evolved alongside their emphasis on the Imams' role as protectors of correct guidance. Practically, this manifests in Shia spirituality prioritizing adherence to Imam-derived teachings, whereas Sunni traditions emphasize direct engagement with Quranic texts and prophetic precedents. Both approaches, however, maintain the verse's core warning against spiritual complacency and false authorities.

In Surah Al-Furqaan verse 17, Allah paints a vivid scene of the Day of Judgment, where He gathers humanity alongside the false deities they worshipped — idols, worldly obsessions, or misguided ideologies. 18.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan verse 18, Allah recounts the Day of Judgment when those who rejected divine guidance will humbly acknowledge their error in worshipping false allies (awliya) instead of Him. The verse captures their admission: "Subhanaka!" ("Exalted are You!"), affirming Allah’s absolute perfection while confessing they wrongly prioritized worldly comforts over His remembrance (dhikr). This confession reflects their belated realization that material prosperity—granted to them and their ancestors as a test—became a trap, causing them to neglect spiritual truths until they became "qawman bura" (a ruined people), spiritually bankrupt.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains this verse as addressing the Meccan polytheists who clung to ancestral traditions and mocked Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) for lacking wealth or power. The term "awliya" (allies/protectors) refers to their false gods and reliance on temporal power, contrasting with the Quran’s call to recognize Allah as the only true Wali (Guardian). The "comforts" (matta’ta) they enjoyed—wealth, social status, or false security—distracted them from reflecting on divine purpose, leading to spiritual amnesia. Historical context reveals this as part of the Quran’s broader critique of arrogant rejection (istikbar) of truth, a theme central to struggles between prophetic messages and oppressive systems.

Today, this verse warns against modern forms of "forgetting" Allah—prioritizing materialism, social validation, or ideologies that replace divine guidance. The phrase "nasiya al-dhikr" (forgetting the Reminder) applies to neglecting Quranic ethics, prayer, or the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings for fleeting gains. Practical lessons include self-auditing: Do worldly comforts numb our moral vigilance? Do we seek "awliya" in corrupt systems or shallow trends? By reviving daily dhikr—through Quranic reflection, gratitude, and conscious detachment from false securities—we align with the verse’s timeless call to recognize Allah as our ultimate Protector and purpose.
18.layer2:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:18), the verse captures the disbelievers’ admission of their error in associating partners with Allah, acknowledging that worldly comforts led them to neglect divine remembrance. Classical Shia exegetes like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize the theological implications of this confession, particularly its alignment with Shia doctrines of divine justice (*‘adl*) and the necessity of recognizing Allah’s exclusive guardianship (*wilayah*).

Tabrisi notes that the phrase *"But You provided comforts for them"* underscores Allah’s mercy in granting material blessings as a test (*ibtila*), not as a sign of approval. This aligns with the Shia understanding that worldly prosperity often becomes a trial leading to spiritual negligence. The “comforts” (*matta’ta*) here symbolize both material wealth and the intellectual complacency of relying on ancestral traditions (*taqlid*) without critical engagement with divine guidance.

Tabatabai expands on *"they forgot the message"* (*nasu al-dhikr*), interpreting *dhikr* not merely as ritual remembrance but as the entirety of prophetic revelation preserved through the Ahl al-Bayt. This reflects the Shia belief that true *dhikr* encompasses adherence to the divinely appointed Imams, whose authority safeguards the Qur’an’s esoteric (*batin*) dimensions. Forgetting the *dhikr*, therefore, signifies rejecting the Imamah—a theological pillar unique to Shia thought—which leads to collective ruin (*qawman buran*).

Both commentators link the verse to broader principles of divine accountability: Allah’s provision is a trust (*amanah*), and its misuse invalidates one’s claim to true *tawhid*. The ruin (*buran*) described is both moral and existential, stemming from prioritizing transient comforts over eternal truths. This aligns with Shia jurisprudence’s emphasis on detachment (*zuhd*) from worldly excess and the ethical obligation to uphold justice through allegiance (*tawalli*) to divine guides.

In essence, the verse serves as a caution against conflating Allah’s temporary blessings with eternal favor, reiterating the Shia axiom that salvation lies in unwavering devotion to divine *tawhid* and the guardianship of the Ahl al-Bayt.
18.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Furqan 25:18 is often interpreted as a profound critique of materialism and spiritual neglect in modern societies. Scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasize that the verse highlights how worldly comforts, when disconnected from divine purpose, breed forgetfulness (ghaflah) of ethical and spiritual consciousness. The “allies” (awliya) mentioned in the verse are not merely pre-Islamic idols but symbolize modern obsessions—consumerism, unchecked capitalism, or even digital distractions—that replace God as the center of human focus. This aligns with philosopher Abdolkarim Soroush’s analysis of how modernity’s “idolatry of progress” risks reducing spirituality to a superficial ritual.

Modern scientific studies on materialism reinforce this view: research in psychology links excessive materialism to decreased life satisfaction and weakened community bonds, mirroring the Quranic warning of a “people ruined.” Socially, the verse resonates with issues like climate collapse, where overconsumption exploits natural resources, and rising mental health crises tied to existential voids in hyper-competitive societies. Scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim connect this to the Shia emphasis on *Tawhid* (divine unity), urging balance between worldly life and transcendent values.

Interfaith parallels abound: Buddhist teachings on detachment, Christian critiques of greed, and eco-theology’s call for stewardship all echo the verse’s warning. In multicultural contexts, the verse challenges both secular and religious communities to re-examine their “idols”—whether nationalist ideologies or algorithmic biases—that fragment human solidarity. For Shia thought, the solution lies in reviving the Ahlul Bayt’s model of social justice and *dhikr* (remembrance), transforming comfort into gratitude and responsibility rather than complacency. This verse thus becomes a timeless mirror, reflecting humanity’s recurring test: to use blessings as tools for collective uplift, not self-destruction.
18.layer4:
In Surah Furqan verse 18, Allah recounts the lamentation of those who neglected divine guardianship (Wilayah) and became spiritually ruined through worldly indulgence. The Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that this verse unveils the peril of prioritizing material comforts over the "Divine Remembrance" - which our Imams clarify is not merely ritual worship, but conscious adherence to the Muhammadan Path embodied in their guidance. 

Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The 'allies besides Allah' mentioned here are the false leaders and tyrants whom people followed instead of the true Imams. The 'comforts' refer to their obsession with worldly gains that made them abandon the remembrance of Allah's chosen ones." This aligns with Imam Ali's (as) warning in Nahj al-Balagha: "The world is a vehicle - ride it to your hereafter, don't let it ride you to destruction."

The verse's condemnation of those who "forgot the message" resonates with the Shia understanding of *Ghaflah* (spiritual forgetfulness) - a state cured only through adherence to the Imam of one's time. Lady Fatimah (as) stated in her Fadak Sermon: "People attain deliverance through following the Imams, and face ruin through opposing them." The "ruined people" here are those who rejected the living guidance of the Ahlul Bayt despite clear proofs.

Practical guidance emerges: 1) Regularly study the supplications of Sahifa Sajjadiya to counter spiritual forgetfulness 2) Perform nightly prayers with contemplation on Imam Mahdi's (aj) occultation 3) Detach from excessive materialism by giving obligatory khums and voluntary charity. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) teaches in Du'a Abu Hamza Thumali: "The true richness is in longing for You, and the real poverty is in being veiled from You." 18.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 25:18, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes of divine transcendence (tanzih) and the dangers of worldly attachment. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) in *Majma al-Bayan* agree the verse depicts polytheists confessing their error on Judgment Day, recognizing Allah’s exclusive right to worship. Both traditions emphasize that material prosperity led earlier communities to neglect divine guidance (*dhikr*), with al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and al-Tusi (Shia) in *At-Tibyan* defining *dhikr* as prophetic teachings. This shared understanding reinforces theological principles of tawhid and accountability across Islamic schools.

Divergences emerge in contextualizing "allies" (*awliya*) and the nature of misguidance. Shia commentators like al-Qummi and Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) interpret the rejection of false *awliya* as implicitly affirming the necessity of divinely appointed leadership (Imamate), arguing that neglecting the Ahl al-Bayt constitutes a form of forgetting *dhikr*. Sunni scholars like Ibn Kathir and al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) focus on explicit polytheism, interpreting *awliya* as idols or false deities. This reflects differing theological emphases: Shia readings integrate Imamology into Quranic exegesis, while Sunni interpretations prioritize combating explicit shirk.

Historically, these differences stem from variant approaches to authority narratives. Shia tafsir often links verses to events involving the Prophet’s household (e.g., Ghadir Khumm), whereas Sunni exegesis generally avoids such specific political-historical connections. Practically, Shia applications may stress loyalty to the Imams as safeguarding against misguidance, while Sunni teachings emphasize communal adherence to Quran and Sunnah. Both traditions, however, utilize this verse to warn against materialism’s spiritual dangers, demonstrating shared ethical concerns despite distinct hermeneutical frameworks.

In Surah Al-Furqan verse 18, Allah recounts the Day of Judgment when those who rejected divine guidance will humbly acknowledge their error in worshipping false allies (awliya) instead of Him. The verse captures their admission: "Subhanaka!" ("Exalted are You!"), affirming Allah’s absolute perfection while confessing they wrongly prioritized worldly comforts over His remembrance (dhikr). This confession reflects their belated realization that material prosperity—granted to them and their ancestors as a test—became a trap, causing them to neglect spiritual truths until they became "qawman bura" (a ruined people), spiritually bankrupt. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "The 'allies besides Allah' mentioned here are the false leaders and tyrants whom people followed instead of the true Imams. Practical lessons include self-auditing: Do worldly comforts numb our moral vigilance? Do we seek "awliya" in corrupt systems or shallow trends? By reviving daily dhikr—through Quranic reflection, gratitude, and conscious detachment from false securities—we align with the verse’s timeless call to recognize Allah as our ultimate Protector and purpose.

19.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:19), Allah addresses the stubborn rejection of truth by those opposing the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), warning disbelievers that their denial of divine guidance will leave them powerless to escape consequences. The verse’s phrase *فَقَدْ كَذَّبُوكُم بِمَا تَقُولُونَ* ("they will deny you in what you say") reflects the Quraysh’s fierce rejection of the Prophet’s message in Mecca, mocking his call to monotheism and resurrection. Their arrogance is met with divine assertion that neither *صَرْفًۭا* (avertance) of punishment nor *نَصْرًۭا* (victory) can be achieved without Allah’s will—a reminder that human power is illusory before divine decree.  

The warning *وَمَن يَظْلِم مِّنكُمْ نُذِقْهُ عَذَابًۭا كَبِيرًۭا* ("whoever commits injustice among you, We will make him taste a great punishment") emphasises *zulm* (injustice), which classical Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai link to rejecting truth or oppressing others. Historically, this applied to persecutors of early Muslims, but its timeless meaning extends to any oppression—whether denying the rights of others, silencing truth, or violating social justice—a core theme in Shia ethics tied to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings.  

Today, this verse urges Muslims to recognise that defiance of divine truth—whether through moral corruption, exploitation, or rejecting spiritual guidance—invites collective and individual downfall. Practically, it calls for self-accountability: avoiding *zulm* in speech, actions, or systems, and trusting that injustice never prevails eternally. For Shia Muslims, it reinforces loyalty to the Quran and the Imams as safeguards against deviation, reminding believers that true success lies in aligning with divine justice, not transient power.
19.layer2:
In Surah al-Furqan (25:19), the verse underscores the futility of the disbelievers’ rejection of divine truth and the inevitability of divine justice. Classical Shia commentators anchor their analysis in the theological principles of divine authority (wilayah) and the consequences of opposing it. Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, interprets the phrase "they will deny you in what you say" as a reference to the disbelievers’ rejection of the Prophet Muhammad’s (ṣ) message and, by extension, the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt (ع). This denial is framed not merely as intellectual dissent but as a moral corruption rooted in *dhulm* (injustice), violating the covenant of recognizing divine authority. Tabatabai emphasizes that the verse’s warning—"you cannot avert [punishment] or [find] help"—reflects the ontological dependence of creation on Allah’s will; neither human stratagems nor false deities can alter divine decree.

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the linguistic nuance of *man yazlim* ("whoever commits injustice"), noting that in Shia exegesis, *zulm* here transcends generic wrongdoing to signify the rejection of *wilayat al-Imamah*—the guardianship of the Imams as successors to the Prophet. This theological pivot aligns with the Shia doctrine that denial of the Imams’ leadership constitutes a rupture in the divine covenant, inviting severe chastisement. The "great punishment" (*adhab kabir*) is interpreted as both a worldly consequence—manifest in spiritual deprivation and societal discord—and an eschatological reckoning. 

The verse also resonates with Shia juridical principles, as obstructing divine guidance violates the obligation to "enjoin good and forbid evil" (al-amr bil-ma’ruf). Classical scholars link this to the broader cosmic struggle between truth and falsehood, wherein loyalty to the Ahl al-Bayt becomes the criterion for salvation. Thus, the verse epitomizes the Shia worldview: divine justice is inseparable from fidelity to the Prophet’s progeny, and opposition to this truth invites inescapable retribution.
19.layer3:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:19), the Quran addresses the futility of denying divine truth and the consequences of systemic injustice—a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi contextualize within modern ethical frameworks. He emphasizes that the verse’s warning against “denial” (takdhib) extends beyond theological rejection to include dismissing universal moral principles, such as human dignity and ecological responsibility. This aligns with Imam Ali’s teachings in *Nahj al-Balagha*, where societal corruption stems from abandoning justice, a concept echoed in today’s discussions on climate denialism or human rights violations.  

Modern scholars, including Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari, link the “great punishment” to the natural consequences of unethical systems. For instance, environmental degradation—a form of “injustice” against the Earth—manifests as climate disasters, resonating with the Quranic principle that oppression disrupts cosmic balance. Socially, the verse critiques structural inequities: economic exploitation, racism, or war, which Islamic ethics frame as collective *zulm* (oppression) demanding redress.  

Philosophically, thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali reinterpret “avert[ing] punishment” as humanity’s inability to escape the cause-effect laws governing existence, whether physical (e.g., pandemics from ecological abuse) or societal (e.g., conflict rooted in greed). Interfaith parallels emerge here: Buddhist teachings on karma and Christian notions of “reaping what you sow” mirror this Quranic causality.  

In a polarized world, this verse urges accountability beyond legalistic compliance, advocating for a holistic ethical consciousness. It challenges modern societies to confront denialism—whether in science, history, or empathy—and to recognize justice as the bedrock of survival, a message as urgent for climate summits as for social justice movements like Black Lives Matter.
19.layer4:
In Surah Al-Furqan, verse 19, Allah warns of the consequences of rejecting divine truth and oppressing the innocent—a theme deeply intertwined with the mission of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). The verse’s declaration, *“whoever commits injustice among you—We will make him taste a great punishment,”* is illuminated by the teachings of Imam Ali (peace be upon him), who said: **“Oppression is the darkness on the Day of Resurrection”** (Bihar al-Anwar). The *zulm* (injustice) here transcends mere worldly tyranny; it signifies rejecting the *Wilayah* (divinely ordained guardianship) of the Ahlul Bayt, the spiritual axis of creation.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) interpreted this verse as a warning against those who distort the truth of the Qur’an and deny the rights of the Prophet’s household, stating: **“The greatest injustice is to claim partnership with Allah or to oppose His Hujjah [divine proof]”** (Tafsir al-Qummi). The *“denial”* in the verse thus refers to rejecting the Imamah, for the Ahlul Bayt are the living *Tafsir* (interpretation) of the Qur’an. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) echoed this in her famed sermon: **“Whoever establishes themselves upon our Wilayah will be saved from the ‘great punishment.’”**  

Practically, this verse calls believers to align their hearts and actions with the *Ma’rifah* (divine recognition) of the Imams. Spiritual protection lies in adhering to their guidance, seeking their intercession, and upholding justice by defending their cause. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) taught in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyyah*: **“The key to salvation is obedience to the Chosen Ones of Allah.”** Let this verse remind us to purify our intentions, repent for any negligence toward the Ahlul Bayt’s rights, and anchor our faith in their luminous teachings.

19.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Furqan 25:19, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while diverging in contextual emphasis. Classical scholars across traditions, including Sunni commentators Tabari and Qurtubi, agree the verse addresses the inevitability of divine justice for those who reject truth, stressing humanity’s inability to evade Allah’s decree. Shia sources like Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* similarly underscore universal divine retribution, framing the verse as a warning against oppression (*zulm*) and denial of prophetic truth. Both traditions link the “great punishment” to eschatological consequences, with Ibn Kathir and Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi* noting its resonance with Quranic themes of accountability.

Key differences emerge in contextualizing the “injustice” (*zulm*) mentioned. Sunni scholars like Razi and Qurtubi often interpret this broadly, addressing moral and social oppression faced by early Muslim communities, particularly the Quraysh’s rejection of the Prophet. In contrast, Shia commentaries such as Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* and Qummi’s work emphasize the verse’s applicability to those who opposed the Ahl al-Bayt, viewing their marginalization as a paradigmatic injustice. Tabatabai further ties this to the theological concept of *walayah*, arguing that rejecting divinely appointed leadership constitutes a grave transgression.

These interpretations reflect distinct theological foundations: Sunni exegesis prioritizes communal ethics and historical context, while Shia readings integrate Imamate theology. Practically, this influences Shia emphasis on loyalty to the Imams as a spiritual obligation, whereas Sunni discourse reinforces adherence to prophetic tradition and collective moral responsibility. Historically, these divergences stem from early debates about leadership and authority after the Prophet’s death, crystallizing into distinct hermeneutical frameworks. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message: divine justice transcends human power, and oppression invites inexorable reckoning.

20.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan verse 20, Allah addresses a common objection faced by Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) and earlier prophets: the demand for "miraculous" proof of prophethood beyond their human nature. The verse begins by affirming that **all messengers (mursaleen)** before Muhammad were fully human—they ate food, engaged in trade, and lived ordinary lives. This rejects the false expectation that prophets should be angelic or detached from worldly realities, emphasizing that their spiritual authority stems from divine guidance, not supernatural status. The Arabic phrase **"la ya'kuluna at-ta’am wa yamshuna fil-aswaq"** ("they ate food and walked in markets") underscores their tangible humanity, a recurring theme in Shia tafsir to counter deification of religious figures and affirm the accessibility of prophetic examples.  

The verse then states Allah made humans a **fitnah** (trial) for one another, testing their capacity for patience in navigating social, ethical, and theological differences. Historically, this responded to Quraysh leaders who mocked the Prophet’s humble lifestyle and the early Muslims’ social marginalization. Shia commentaries, such as those by Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, explain that societal hierarchies, conflicts, and even persecution are divinely permitted tests to distinguish genuine faith from hypocrisy.  

Today, this verse reminds Muslims that challenges like inequality, ideological divisions, or interpersonal friction are opportunities to practice **sabr** (patience) and trust in Allah’s wisdom. The closing phrase **"wa kana Rabbuka basira"** ("your Lord is Seeing") reassures believers that divine justice observes their responses to these trials. For Shia communities, this aligns with the ethos of enduring oppression with dignity, as exemplified by the Ahlul Bayt, while actively upholding truth and compassion. Ultimately, the verse calls Muslims to embrace prophetic humility, recognize tests as spiritual catalysts, and anchor their conduct in Allah’s eternal awareness.
20.layer2:
In *Tafsīr al-Mīzān*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates Surah al-Furqān 25:20 by emphasizing the ontological parity between Prophet Muhammad (ṣ) and previous prophets, underscoring their shared human nature. The verse’s assertion that all messengers “ate food and walked in markets” negates any notion of prophets possessing supernatural or divine qualities, affirming instead their role as *bashar* (human beings) tasked with guiding humanity through lived example. Tabatabai explains this as a rebuttal to those who dismissed prophethood based on the Prophet’s ordinary human traits, arguing that divine messaging hinges not on otherworldly attributes but on divine selection (*iṣmat*) and moral infallibility. This aligns with Shia theology’s emphasis on prophets and Imams as perfected yet fully human guides, distinct from incarnational or angelic conceptions.

Tabrisi, in *Majma‘ al-Bayān*, expands on the phrase “We made some of you a trial for others,” interpreting it through the lens of divine testing (*ibtilā’*). He links this to the Shia concept of *imtiḥān* (trials of faith), where societal disparities—wealth, status, or knowledge—serve to manifest human moral choices. The rhetorical question “Will you have patience?” invokes the virtue of *ṣabr* (steadfastness), central to Shia spirituality, particularly in contexts of injustice or oppression. Tabrisi notes that such trials expose hypocrisy and strengthen the faithful, echoing Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teaching that “trials are the scales of hearts” (*Biḥār al-Anwār*).

The verse’s conclusion—“your Lord is Seeing”—reinforces the Shia doctrine of divine omniscience, assuring accountability for responses to these trials. Classical commentaries tie this to theodicy, asserting that worldly inequalities are divinely ordained to cultivate spiritual growth, a theme recurrent in Shia narratives about the Ahl al-Bayt’s endurance under persecution. Jurisprudentially, this verse underpins the ethical obligation to interact justly within societal frameworks, as markets symbolize communal life where moral integrity is tested. Thus, the verse synthesizes theology, ethics, and eschatology, reflecting the Shia worldview’s integration of divine wisdom with human responsibility.
20.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Furqan 25:20 is often framed as a profound affirmation of prophetic humanity and a call to navigate modern social complexities with spiritual resilience. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in *Tafsir Nemuneh*, underscores that prophets like Muhammad (PBUH) rejected elitism, embracing ordinary life to model humility and accessibility. Today, this resonates in critiques of corrupt leadership and consumerist excess; the "walking in markets" motif challenges societies obsessed with materialism, urging leaders to remain grounded amid power dynamics.

Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect the verse’s emphasis on "trials among people" to contemporary social fragmentation—economic inequality, xenophobia, or digital echo chambers that polarize communities. The Quranic question "Will you have patience?" (أَتَصْبِرُونَ) speaks to sabr (perseverance) as active endurance, akin to civil rights struggles or climate activism demanding sustained moral courage. Neuroscientific studies on empathy and cooperation, cited by thinkers like Dr. Mustafa Akram, align with the verse’s implicit call to view diversity as a test of ethical growth rather than division.

Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’s critiques of economic exploitation or Buddhist teachings on mindful consumption, highlighting shared ethics across traditions. Philosophically, the verse challenges existential individualism; as Professor Liyakat Takim notes, our interconnectedness in global crises—pandemics, migration—mirrors the "trial" of transcending ego to build collective resilience. Ultimately, the verse’s closure—"your Lord is Seeing"—reassures believers navigating an age of surveillance capitalism and algorithmic bias that divine justice transcends human myopia, urging accountability in both personal and systemic realms.
20.layer4:
The verse from Surah Al-Furqaan (25:20) unveils profound truths about the nature of divine guidance and humanity’s spiritual trials. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that Allah’s messengers and chosen guides, though appearing as ordinary beings who "eat food and walk in markets," carried the light of wilayah (divine authority) within their human forms. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Allah’s proofs [hujaj] walk among you, dressed in cloaks like yours, sitting in your gatherings—but they see with His light and act by His wisdom." This underscores that the essence of prophethood and imamah transcends physical appearance; true recognition requires spiritual insight.

The phrase "We made some of you a trial for others" is deeply tied to the Shia understanding of divine testing through the presence of the Imams. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains: "People are tested by people, just as gold is tested by fire. The believer is tested by those who reject the guardians [awliya] of Allah." Here, the "trial" lies in recognizing divine authority in the Imams despite their outward humility and the world’s rejection of them. This mirrors the struggles faced by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family), whose mission was mocked by those who reduced him to a "mere man who eats food."

Practical wisdom from this verse calls believers to cultivate *sabr* (patience) in adhering to the truth amid societal pressures. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught: "The one who places Allah’s commands as a lamp before their heart will never stumble in darkness." To walk the path of the Ahlul Bayt, one must see beyond materialism, uphold loyalty to divine guides, and transform worldly interactions into opportunities for spiritual refinement. The verse concludes by affirming Allah’s all-encompassing vision (Baseer), reminding us that true sight lies in perceiving His signs in the apparent and the hidden.

سورہ الفرقان آیت 20 میں ، اللہ حضرت محمد (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) اور اس سے قبل کے نبیوں کو درپیش ایک مشترکہ اعتراض سے خطاب کرتا ہے: ان کی انسانی فطرت سے بالاتر پیشن گوئی کے "معجزاتی" ثبوت کا مطالبہ۔ اس آیت کا آغاز اس بات کی تصدیق سے ہوتا ہے کہ ** تمام میسینجرز (مرسالین) ** اس سے پہلے کہ محمد مکمل طور پر انسان تھے۔ انہوں نے کھانا کھایا ، تجارت میں مصروف ، اور عام زندگی گزارے۔ اس سے اس جھوٹی توقع کو مسترد کردیا گیا ہے کہ نبیوں کو فرشتہ ہونا چاہئے یا دنیاوی حقائق سے الگ ہونا چاہئے ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ ان کا روحانی اختیار الوکک حیثیت سے نہیں بلکہ الہی رہنمائی سے ہے۔ عربی کے فقرے ** "لا یاکولونا ایٹ-تام وا یامشونا فل-اسواق" ** ("انہوں نے کھانا کھایا اور بازاروں میں چلتے ہوئے") ان کی ٹھوس انسانیت کی نشاندہی کی ، جو شیعہ طافسیر میں مذہبی اعدادوشمار کے ڈیفیکیشن کا مقابلہ کرنے اور پیشن گوئی کے امتحانات کی رسائ کی تصدیق کے لئے ایک بار بار چلنے والا موضوع ہے۔  

اس کے بعد اس آیت میں کہا گیا ہے کہ اللہ نے انسانوں کو ایک دوسرے کے لئے ** فٹنہ ** (آزمائش) بنا دیا ، اور معاشرتی ، اخلاقی اور مذہبی اختلافات کو نیویگیٹ کرنے میں صبر کی صلاحیت کی جانچ کی۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس نے قریش کے رہنماؤں کو جواب دیا جنہوں نے نبی کے عاجز طرز زندگی اور ابتدائی مسلمانوں کی معاشرتی پسماندگی کا مذاق اڑایا۔ شیعہ کی تبصرے ، جیسے *المزان *میں الامہ تبتابائی کے ذریعہ ، وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ معاشرتی درجہ بندی ، تنازعات ، اور یہاں تک کہ ظلم و ستم بھی حقیقی عقیدے کو منافقت سے ممتاز کرنے کے لئے امتحانات کی اجازت ہے۔  

آج ، یہ آیت مسلمانوں کو یاد دلاتی ہے کہ عدم مساوات ، نظریاتی ڈویژنوں ، یا باہمی رگڑ جیسی چیلنجز ** صابر ** (صبر) پر عمل کرنے کے مواقع ہیں اور اللہ کی حکمت پر اعتماد ہے۔ اختتامی جملہ ** "وا کنا ربوبوکا بسیرا" ** ("آپ کا رب دیکھ رہا ہے") مومنوں کو یقین دلاتا ہے کہ خدائی انصاف ان آزمائشوں پر ان کے ردعمل کا مشاہدہ کرتا ہے۔ شیعہ برادریوں کے ل this ، یہ وقار کے ساتھ ظلم برداشت کرنے کے اخلاق کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے ، جیسا کہ اہل بیت نے مثال کے طور پر سچائی اور ہمدردی کو برقرار رکھا ہے۔ بالآخر ، آیت مسلمانوں کو پیشن گوئی عاجزی کو قبول کرنے ، ٹیسٹوں کو روحانی اتپریرک کے طور پر تسلیم کرنے اور اللہ کی ابدی بیداری میں ان کے طرز عمل کو لنگر انداز کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔

20.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Furqan 25:20, Shia and Sunni scholars converge on core themes while diverging in nuanced emphases. Both traditions universally affirm the verse’s primary message: prophets’ humanity and accessibility, refuting claims of their divinity. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that prophets’ engagement in mundane activities like eating and trading underscores their mortal nature, aligning with Quranic rejections of deification. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Al-Tabtabai (Al-Mizan) similarly stress this egalitarian principle, emphasizing that prophets’ human limitations validate their role as relatable guides.

Divergences emerge in interpreting “We have made some of you a trial for others.” Sunni exegetes like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) often frame this as a general test of societal hierarchies, where wealth, status, or power challenge believers’ spiritual resolve. In contrast, Shia sources like Tafsir al-Qummi and Al-Tusi (At-Tibyan) contextualize this within Imamology, viewing the Ahl al-Bayt’s elevated status and their adversaries as part of a divine trial. Al-Tabtabai extends this to cosmic justice, where loyalty to divinely appointed guides becomes a criterion for salvation—a perspective rooted in Shia theology’s emphasis on walaya (guardianship).

Practically, Sunni interpretations encourage patience amid social inequities, fostering individual piety. Shia readings often link this “trial” to historical persecution of the Imams, reinforcing communal identity through commemorative practices. These differences stem from distinct historical experiences: Sunni exegesis developed in contexts prioritizing communal unity under caliphal rule, while Shia hermeneutics evolved amid narratives of marginalization and allegiance to the Imamate.

Both traditions ultimately affirm God’s omniscience (“your Lord is Seeing”) as the ethical anchor, though their theological frameworks shape distinct applications. Such variations reflect Islam’s rich interpretative diversity while maintaining shared reverence for prophetic exemplars.

In Surah Al-Furqan verse 20, Allah addresses a common objection faced by Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) and earlier prophets: the demand for "miraculous" proof of prophethood beyond their human nature. 21.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan verse 21, Allah addresses the stubborn demands of disbelievers who rejected Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) by asking for physical, miraculous proofs like angels descending or directly seeing God. Historical accounts note this verse responded to Meccan polytheists who—despite witnessing the Quran’s linguistic miracles and moral teachings—insisted on supernatural spectacles as a precondition for faith. Their demand was insincere, rooted in istikbar (arrogance), a key term here meaning prideful rejection of truth. The phrase "la yarjuna liqa'ana" (do not expect the meeting with Us) reveals their denial of resurrection and divine accountability, exposing a deeper spiritual blindness. The word "atuwwan" (insolence) underscores their rebellion against submitting to Allah’s chosen guidance.  

Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s Al-Mizan, emphasises that such demands reflect a materialistic worldview rejecting ghayb (the unseen). The Ahlul Bayt taught that true faith requires recognising Allah’s signs through wisdom and inner reflection, not sensory coercion. For instance, Imam Ali (as) stated, "Allah is not seen by eyes, but hearts see Him through the truths of faith." Today, this verse warns Muslims against equating faith with tangible "proofs" or expecting religion to conform to limited human logic. Modern arrogance manifests in dismissing divine laws or spiritual truths because they challenge personal desires or societal trends. Practically, this calls for humility, trusting Allah’s wisdom in conveying guidance through prophets and Imams—divinely appointed guides—rather than seeking spectacle. By embracing tawakkul (reliance on God) and resisting the arrogance of demanding "visible" validation, believers strengthen their connection to the unseen realities central to Islam.
21.layer2:
In this verse from Surah al-Furqan, Allah addresses the objections of disbelievers demanding tangible proofs of revelation through angelic manifestations or direct divine vision. Classical Shia exegetes interpret this as reflecting a fundamental misunderstanding of divine wisdom and prophetic purpose. Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* observes that such demands stem from spiritual arrogance (*istikbar*) rooted in prioritizing sensory perception over inner recognition (*ma'rifa*). The request to "see our Lord" contradicts the Qur'anic principle that divine essence transcends physical perception (6:103), making their demand a pretext for evasion rather than sincere inquiry.

Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualises this verse within recurring Meccan objections to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), noting that divine communication through human messengers – rather than direct angelic intervention – affirms Allah's mercy in accommodating human capacities. The Shia tradition emphasises that true recognition occurs through the heart's submission to divine signs (ayat) and acknowledgement of the Prophetic mission and its continuation through the Imams of Ahl al-Bayt. The verse's condemnation of "great insolence" (*utuwwn kabiran*) is interpreted by scholars like Shaykh Tusi as reflecting the ontological rebellion of those rejecting the hierarchy of divine guidance (walaya), wherein refusal to accept prophetic authority parallels the primordial sin of Iblis.

Theologically, this verse underscores the Shia principle that divine proofs (hujaj) are perfected through human messengers and their divinely appointed successors, not through coercive miracles that override free will. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq's teachings, cited in *Tafsir al-Qummi*, link such demands to materialist worldviews (*asabiyyat al-maddiyyin*) that reduce spiritual truth to physical evidence. The verse thus reinforces the doctrinal stance that faith requires embracing the unseen (ghayb) through intellectual humility and acceptance of prophetic and Imamic guidance, rather than seeking sensory domination over metaphysical realities. This aligns with broader Shia jurisprudential emphasis on taqlid (emulation) of divinely authenticated guides as the path to true ma'rifa.
21.layer3:
In Surah Al-Furqan 25:21, the Quran critiques those demanding tangible "proofs" of divine reality—a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi contextualise within modern materialism’s obsession with empirical validation. This verse exposes a timeless human tendency: equating truth solely with what is physically observable, a mindset amplified today by scientism and hyperrationalism. Scholars note parallels between the disbelievers’ demand to "see angels" and modern dismissals of spirituality unless "proven" by laboratory methods, highlighting how both reflect epistemic arrogance.  

Contemporary thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to Imam Ali’s teachings in *Nahj al-Balagha*, which emphasise recognising divine subtlety in creation’s complexity—a concept resonant with scientific discoveries about dark matter or quantum fields, phenomena unseen yet foundational to cosmic order. The verse’s indictment of *istikbar* (arrogance) speaks directly to social systems built on human exceptionalism, from environmental exploitation to AI ethics debates that sideline moral accountability.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with traditions like Buddhism (emphasising impermanence) or Judaism (questioning idolatry of the visible), enrich this discourse. The verse also critiques rising global individualism; as scholar Fatemeh Fakhraie argues, demands for “personalised miracles” mirror consumerist spirituality that reduces faith to transactional convenience. In an age of deepfakes and misinformation, the verse invites reclaiming humility—embracing the unseen as a bridge between spiritual wisdom and scientific curiosity, urging societies to transcend literalism for holistic understanding.
21.layer4:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:21), Allah exposes the spiritual blindness of those who demand physical "proofs" of the unseen, such as seeing angels or the Divine Essence, as a precondition for faith. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that such demands stem from arrogance (istikbār) and a refusal to submit to the tests of divine wisdom. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "The eyes cannot see Him in ocular observation, but hearts perceive Him through the realities of faith" (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 179). The verse critiques those who prioritize sensory perception over the luminous guidance of the Imamah, which is the true "face" of Allah’s presence in creation.  

The Sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him), explains that the demand for angels to descend is a veiled rejection of Allah’s chosen guides: "They say, ‘Send us angels!’ But if We sent angels, the matter would be decreed, and they would not be reprieved" (Tafsir al-Qummi). Here, the Imam links the verse to the rejection of prophetic and Imamic authority, emphasizing that angels *do* descend—not as mere spectacles, but through the divine light vested in the Ahlul Bayt, who are the mediators of heavenly knowledge.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declares in her famed sermon, "Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and our Wilayah the pillar of Islam" (Bihar al-Anwar). To demand physical "signs" while ignoring the living miracle of the Imams’ infallible guidance is to repeat the arrogance of those condemned in this verse.  

: True vision of Allah is attained not through the eyes but through recognizing the divine light in the Ahlul Bayt. Cultivate humility by studying their teachings, reflecting on their sacrifices, and embracing their Wilayah as the path to spiritual awakening. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "Whoever recognizes himself has recognized his Lord" (Ghurar al-Hikam)—a recognition rooted in submitting to the guides Allah has appointed.

21.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge in interpreting this verse as addressing the obstinacy of disbelievers who demanded supernatural proofs to validate Prophet Muhammad’s message. Classical commentators like Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) contextualize the verse within the Quraysh’s rejection of revelation, noting their unreasonable requests for angelic visitations or direct divine manifestation. Ibn Kathir and Al-Mizan’s Tabatabai agree that such demands stemmed from arrogance (*istikbar*) and a refusal to submit to spiritual truth, emphasizing that faith requires acceptance of divine wisdom beyond physical evidence.  

A key divergence arises in theological implications. Sunni scholars such as Qurtubi and Razi focus on the impossibility of seeing God in this life (Qurtubi cites Q. 7:143) and stress that angels were sent metaphorically through revelation. Shia commentators like Tusi and Qummi extend this discourse, with Tabatabai noting that rejecting *walayah* (divine guardianship through the Ahl al-Bayt) parallels the Quraysh’s rejection of prophethood, framing both as forms of spiritual blindness. This reflects the Shia theological emphasis on *imamah* as a continuation of divine guidance.  

Historically, Sunni interpretations often emphasize the universality of the Quran’s moral critique, while Shia exegesis, as seen in Tafsir al-Qummi, occasionally links such verses to post-prophetic struggles over leadership. For instance, the “insolence” (*utuw*) is interpreted as symbolic of rejecting rightful Imams. These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni thought prioritizes the finality of prophethood, whereas Shia theology integrates Imamah into its cosmology of divine guidance.  

Both traditions agree the verse underscores humility before divine revelation, but their applications differ subtly. Sunni practice emphasizes adherence to prophetic precedent, while Shia spirituality incorporates devotion to the Imams as embodiments of ongoing divine connection. Such variations reflect historical and theological developments rather than sectarian conflict, illustrating the richness of Islamic exegetical tradition.

In Surah Al-Furqan verse 21, Allah addresses the stubborn demands of disbelievers who rejected Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) by asking for physical, miraculous proofs like angels descending or directly seeing God. Historical accounts note this verse responded to Meccan polytheists who—despite witnessing the Quran’s linguistic miracles and moral teachings—insisted on supernatural spectacles as a precondition for faith. Their demand was insincere, rooted in istikbar (arrogance), a key term here meaning prideful rejection of truth. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, "The eyes cannot see Him in ocular observation, but hearts perceive Him through the realities of faith" (Nahj al-Balagha, Sermon 179). By embracing tawakkul (reliance on God) and resisting the arrogance of demanding "visible" validation, believers strengthen their connection to the unseen realities central to Islam.

22.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan, verse 22, Allah describes a moment on the Day of Judgment when disbelievers will face angels bearing no glad tidings but uttering *"hijran mahjura"*—a phrase conveying absolute rejection, like a barrier sealing all hope. The verse starkly contrasts divine mercy with the finality of judgment for those who rejected truth. Classical Shia commentaries, such as those by Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, explain that *"la bushra"* (no good news) signifies the end of opportunities for repentance, while *"mujrimin"* (criminals) refers to those who persistently denied Allah’s signs and oppressed His guides, including the Ahlul Bayt. The angels’ declaration "prevented and inaccessible" underscores their irreversible exclusion from divine grace, a theme echoed in Shia narrations about the spiritual consequences of opposing Imam Ali’s wilayah.

This Meccan verse, revealed amid persecution of early Muslims, reassured believers while warning oppressors that their arrogance would culminate in eternal separation from Allah’s mercy. The term *"hijran mahjura"* uses doubled roots for emphasis—*hajr* meaning to forbid or block—painting a vivid image of a sealed partition between the guilty and salvation. 

Today, this verse invites reflection on accountability and the dangers of stubbornness in sin. It reminds Muslims to avoid spiritual "barriers" by aligning actions with Quranic ethics and the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. Practically, it urges humility, seeking forgiveness before worldly choices harden the heart, and recognizing that persistent wrongdoing risks eternal isolation. By valuing truth and justice, believers safeguard themselves from becoming those to whom angels say, *"hijran mahjura.
22.layer2:
In Surah al-Furqan (25:22), the verse depicts the Day of Judgment when the disbelievers witness angels delivering a stark declaration of divine rejection: *"Prevented and inaccessible" (Hijran Mahjura)*. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this as a moment of ultimate separation between divine mercy and those who rejected truth persistently. Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, interprets the angels’ proclamation as an irrevocable denial of intercession (*shafa‘a*) for the unjust. He notes that the verse underscores the principle of divine justice (*‘adl*)—mercy and punishment are contingent on one’s spiritual state, not arbitrary divine will. The phrase *Hijran Mahjura* signifies a double barrier: the disbelievers are both morally disqualified from receiving grace (*hijr*) and existentially cut off (*mahjur*) from proximity to Allah’s mercy, reflecting their own choices in worldly life.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualizes the verse within eschatological themes, explaining that the angels here are agents of divine reckoning, tasked with enforcing the consequences of human actions. He highlights a Hadith from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS) stating that such souls are barred from the "spring of mercy" reserved for the righteous, symbolizing their exclusion from the spiritual nourishment provided by the Ahl al-Bayt (AS). This aligns with Shia theology’s emphasis on the necessity of divine guidance through the Imams, whose leadership (*wilaya*) is the conduit for accessing Allah’s mercy. The verse also resonates with Shia juridical principles, as it reinforces the accountability of moral agency (*taklif*) and the futility of seeking salvation without aligning one’s actions with divine commandments and the teachings of the Prophet’s Household. Thus, the verse serves as both a theological warning and a reminder of the inseparable link between faith, righteous deeds, and the recognition of divine authority embodied in the Ahl al-Bayt (AS)
22.layer3:
In Surah Al-Furqan 25:22, the Qur’an paints a vivid scene of divine accountability where angels deny mercy to those who persistently rejected moral truth. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, frame this “prevented and inaccessible” (*hijran mahjura*) state as a spiritual quarantine—a self-inflicted separation from divine grace resulting from humanity’s ethical failures. This mirrors modern discussions on moral agency: just as social systems collapse when corruption becomes systemic (e.g., political greed, environmental exploitation), the verse warns that souls risk eternal alienation when they normalize injustice.  

Modern thinkers like Dr. Seyed Ammar Nakhjavani link this to the psychology of alienation in a hyperconnected yet fragmented digital age. The “barrier” described isn’t merely physical but existential—a life spent chasing validation through materialism or oppression severs one’s connection to higher purpose. Scientific parallels emerge in studies on guilt and cognitive dissonance: the brain’s anterior cingulate cortex activates when moral boundaries are crossed, suggesting an innate human awareness of ethical "barriers" that the verse cosmically amplifies.  

The verse’s urgency resonates with global crises. Climate collapse, for instance, reflects a collective “hijran mahjura”—humanity’s exploitation of nature triggering irreversible consequences, much like the Qur’anic criminals facing irreversible judgment. Interfaith dialogues, such as those promoted by the Imam Hussein Foundation, highlight shared Abrahamic and Eastern philosophies on karma-like accountability, bridging Islamic eschatology with Buddhist impermanence or Christian reckonings.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern societies to dismantle barriers of greed, apathy, and oppression—calling for a return to justice (*adl*) and compassion (*rahma*), values central to Shia theology and universal human dignity. As Ayatollah Abdullah Javadi-Amoli notes, “The gates of mercy never close, but we build walls with our choices.

erse unveils a moment of divine reckoning when the veils of this world are lifted, and the angels – bearers of mercy and wrath – manifest realities long concealed. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that the "prevented and inaccessible" (حِجْرًا مَّحْجُورًا) state of the criminals stems from their alienation from the light of Wilayah (divine guardianship) in their earthly lives. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The most severe punishment on the Day of Resurrection is for one whom Allah veils from His mercy." This veiling is not arbitrary but a reflection of choices made in rejecting the rope of Allah, the Ahlul Bayt, who are the manifest Ark of Salvation.  

The sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him), elucidates that the angels’ declaration signifies an eternal barrier between the sinful and divine mercy, rooted in their denial of the Imamah. In *Tafsir al-Qummi*, it is narrated that those who severed their connection with the Imams will find their deeds "inaccessible" to acceptance, for "no deed ascends to Allah except through recognition of the Proof [Imam] of the time." Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) warns in her famed sermon: "You are enslaved by your desires; your hearts are barred from the light of guidance."  

Practically, this verse calls believers to anchor their souls in the love and obedience of the Ahlul Bayt, for they are the intermediaries (wasilah) through which divine mercy flows. Daily adherence to their teachings – through seeking knowledge, upholding justice, and nurturing taqwa – erects spiritual barriers *against* sin, not *from* mercy. The supplications taught by the Imams, such as Dua Kumayl, awaken the heart to this reality: "O Allah, forgive me every sin that severs me from Your mercy." In analyzing Surah al-Furqan 25:22, Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions converge on several core themes while diverging in theological nuance. Both schools universally interpret this verse as depicting the Day of Judgment, where angels deny mercy to evildoers. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) agree the phrase "hijran mahjura" signifies absolute exclusion from divine grace, with al-Tusi (Shia) and al-Qurtubi (Sunni) emphasizing its finality as a spiritual barrier against repentance. The consensus across traditions affirms the Quranic principle of eschatological accountability.

Key differences emerge in contextualizing the "prevention" described. Shia commentaries like al-Qummi’s tafsir and Tabatabai’s al-Mizan often link the verse to the rejection of Imam Ali’s wilayah (guardianship), interpreting the angels’ declaration as a denial of intercession (shafa‘a) for those who opposed the Ahl al-Bayt. Conversely, Sunni scholars such as Ibn Kathir and al-Razi frame the exclusion more broadly, attributing it to persistent disbelief (kufr) and moral corruption without specific reference to leadership disputes. Al-Qurtubi adds that the barrier represents Allah’s withdrawal of mercy from unrepentant sinners, aligning with Sunni emphasis on divine omnipotence over covenantal hierarchies.

These interpretations reflect theological priorities: Shia exegesis integrates Imamology into eschatology, while Sunni works prioritize Allah’s direct judgment. Practically, this influences Shia devotional focus on seeking intercession through the Imams, contrasted with Sunni emphasis on individual accountability. Historically, divergent readings stem from early debates over leadership succession and its theological implications, with Shia sources viewing loyalty to the Ahl al-Bayt as inseparable from salvation. Both traditions, however, maintain the verse’s core warning against spiritual negligence, demonstrating shared ethical concerns amidst distinct hermeneutical frameworks.

23.layer1:
In Surah Al-Furqan (25:23), Allah declares, *"Wa qadimna ila ma amiloo min amalin fa ja’alnahu haba’an manthura"* – a profound reminder that deeds disconnected from divine truth become as worthless as scattered dust. This verse, revealed during intense opposition to Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) in Mecca, addresses those who rejected his message while maintaining superficial religious practices. The Quraysh elite, though performing rituals, opposed Islam’s core truths; their deeds, devoid of sincere faith and alignment with revelation, lost all value before Allah.  

The term *amal* (deed) here refers not to actions in general but to acts claiming spiritual merit—prayers, charity, or rituals—that lack the foundation of *tawhid* (monotheism) and adherence to Allah’s guidance. *Haba’an manthura* (scattered dust) evokes an image of complete futility: dust once held together crumbles and vanishes, symbolizing how hollow deeds disintegrate in the Divine assessment. Classical Shia scholars like Allama Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Sheikh Tabarsi (Majma al-Bayan) stress that deeds are judged by their connection to the *Ahlul Bayt*’s teachings. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) taught, “A deed without the recognition of the Imam is like a body without a soul” – underscoring that actions must align with the guidance of the Imams to hold spiritual weight.  

For modern Muslims, this verse urges self-reflection: Are our prayers, fasts, or charity rooted in sincere devotion and obedience to divine principles, or are they performative rituals detached from ethical and spiritual truth? In a world obsessed with image and materialism, it warns against reducing faith to empty formalism. Practically, this means prioritizing intention (*niyyah*), pursuing justice, and aligning actions with the Quran and the Ahlul Bayt’s timeless wisdom. True *amal* flourishes only when grounded in love for Allah, consciousness of the Hereafter, and commitment to the path of those He purified.
23.layer2:
In Surah al-Furqan 25:23, the Quranic declaration that God will render the deeds of certain individuals as "scattered dust" forms a profound theological assertion on the futility of actions divorced from divine guidance and sincerity. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasise that this verse pertains primarily to those who rejected prophetic truth and the spiritual authority (*wilayah*) of the Ahlul Bayt. Tabatabai elucidates that deeds, though outwardly righteous, are nullified when performed without recognition of the ontological reality of divine guardianship (*wilayat al-ilahiyyah*), which is intrinsically tied to the Imams’ role as the "proofs of God" (*hujaj Allah*). This reflects the Shia theological tenet that the acceptance of deeds is contingent upon adherence to the Imam of one’s time, a principle rooted in the Hadith of the Two Weighty Things (*Thaqalayn*), where the Prophet binds salvation to loyalty to the Quran and his progeny.

Similarly, Sheikh Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* underscores the ethical-spiritual dimensions of this annihilation of deeds. He interprets the "scattered dust" as a metaphor for actions devoid of *ikhlas* (sincerity) or performed for worldly validation (*riya*), rendering them ephemeral despite their apparent magnitude. This aligns with the Shia synthesis of outward adherence to jurisprudence (*fiqh*) and inward purity of intention (*niyyah*), a duality emphasised in the teachings of Imam Jafar al-Sadiq. The verse thus serves as a caution against compartmentalising ritual acts from the holistic framework of faith (*iman*), divine love (*mahabba*), and allegiance (*tawalli*) to the Ahlul Bayt. 

Both commentators situate this verse within the broader Shia eschatological vision, where divine justice necessitates the invalidation of deeds rooted in spiritual heedlessness (*ghaflah*). This underscores the inseparable link between orthopraxy and orthodoxy in Shia doctrine, wherein true righteousness emanates from alignment with the luminous guidance of the Imams.
23.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Furqan 25:23 is often interpreted as a profound commentary on the ephemeral nature of worldly pursuits disconnected from divine purpose. Scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasize that deeds lacking sincerity or rooted in arrogance become "scattered dust" not merely in the afterlife but also in their societal impact. This aligns with the Quranic principle that actions must harmonize with *maqasid al-sharia* (higher objectives of Islamic ethics), such as justice and compassion, to endure. Modern thinkers like Dr. Liyakat Takim highlight how the verse critiques materialistic systems that prioritize profit over people, reducing human dignity and ecological balance to "disperse" like fragile particles.  

Scientifically, the imagery of dust evokes entropy—the irreversible degradation of energy—mirrored in environmental crises like desertification, where fertile land turns barren through unsustainable practices. Philosophically, existentialist themes resonate here: the void left by consumerism or performative activism echoes the "hollow deeds" condemned in the verse. Socially, the rise of digital superficiality—where online validation replaces meaningful connection—parallels the transient "dust" of unanchored actions.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Buddhist and Jain traditions, find common ground in critiques of ego-driven endeavors. Climate activists like Greta Thunberg inadvertently echo this Quranic warning by urging societies to abandon short-term gains for sustainable futures. For Shia communities, this verse calls for integrating faith with praxis: nurturing deeds rooted in Imam Ali’s maxim, "Actions are judged by intentions," while addressing modern challenges like inequality and ecological collapse. Ultimately, it bridges timeless spirituality with urgent global imperatives, urging a recalibration of human effort toward enduring, divine-aligned purpose.
23.layer4:
In Surah Al-Furqaan, verse 25:23, Allah warns that even seemingly profound deeds will be reduced to "scattered dust" if devoid of divine acceptance. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate this warning with profound spiritual insights, emphasizing that the value of actions lies not in their outward form but in their alignment with the light of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) and sincere devotion. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, *"A deed, no matter how small, becomes great when it emerges from recognition [of the Truth], and a deed, no matter how great, becomes scattered dust when accompanied by arrogance or performed without the recognition of the rightful guardians of Allah’s covenant."* This underscores the Shia principle that deeds are validated only through conscious adherence to the Imamah and love for the Ahlul Bayt, the spiritual axis of creation.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that actions are "lifted to the heavens by the ropes of sincerity." Without *ikhlas* (purity of intention) and loyalty to the Imams, deeds lack the "spirit" that grants them eternal weight. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) similarly warned, *"Allah does not look at your forms or wealth, but at your hearts and deeds"*—a heart disconnected from the guidance of the Imams remains barren, rendering deeds hollow.  

Practically, this verse urges believers to anchor every act in the love and obedience of the Ahlul Bayt. Reciting *Ziyarat Ashura*, seeking nearness to the Imams through daily supplications, and purifying intentions by aligning them with the Ma’sumin’s teachings are means to infuse deeds with lasting value. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) reminds us, *"The worth of every person lies in the worth of their intentions."* True spirituality begins by letting the light of Wilayah transform our actions from transient dust into eternal jewels.
